content.title: Natural History of Peripheral Arterial Disease
content.definition: The clinical course and progression of atherosclerotic peripheral arterial disease over time, characterized by limb outcomes (claudication, critical limb ischemia, amputation) and cardiovascular events (MI, stroke, cardiovascular death). PAD is a systemic marker of atherosclerosis with significant cardiovascular mortality.

intermittent_claudication.definition: Exercise-induced leg pain, relieved by rest

cardiovascular_outcomes.key_message: PAD patients are more likely to die from MI than lose their leg

polyvascular_disease.risk: Cumulative with each additional bed involved
polyvascular_disease.prevalence: Many PAD patients have subclinical CAD

learning_objectives: Counsel patients on limb vs cardiovascular outcomes
Recognize critical limb ischemia as a high-mortality state
Identify modifiable risk factors affecting progression
clinical_pearls: PAD patients are more likely to die from MI/stroke than lose their leg
70-80% of claudicants remain stable at 5 years
CLI = 25% 1-year mortality - it's a systemic disease marker
Smoking cessation is the single most important intervention
Low ABI predicts cardiovascular mortality even in asymptomatic patients
common_misconceptions: Misconception: PAD is primarily about limb loss - Reality: Cardiovascular death is the main cause of mortality
